learning_outcomes.description: Describe the control, integration, and coordination mechanisms required for oral health.
Understand intracellular and extracellular communication in tissue injury and disease of the oral cavity.
Understand the properties of cell membranes and the application of excitable and non-excitable cells to pharmacology in dental practice.
Demonstrate an understanding of the structure and morphology of oral and craniofacial structures, in the context of regeneration, reconstruction and rehabilitation.
Demonstrate an understanding of homeostasis and control of major physiological systems to manage chronic inflammation and wound healing in the oral cavity.
Apply the concepts of physiology to oral health or disease.
Apply the pharmacological principles of drug treatments to dental practice.

assessments.task_description: This in-semester quiz consists of 20 questions in a range of formats, including multiple-choice questions (MCQs), drag-and-drop questions, and true/false questions, covering Week 1 and Week 2 content. The quiz will be delivered via Inspera and will run for 30 minutes, from 2:00 pm to 2:30 pm.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: Exams submitted after the end of the submission time will incur a late penalty.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
In this task, you are required to compose a 1,000-1,200 words critical essay on how basic science is applied in everyday dental practice. This task is designed to develop your ability to integrate foundational scientific knowledge with clinical reasoning and evidence-based practice. 

Below are some examples to get you started, but feel free to write about a topic of your choosing:

  • How understanding mitosis, epithelial turnover, and cellular communication informs the diagnosis and management of oral mucosal lesions.
  • How knowledge of epithelial histology supports interpretation of clinical signs such as ulceration, white lesions, or mucosal integrity in disease.
  • How principles of drug absorption, metabolism, and excretion influence the safe and effective use of local anaesthetics, analgesics, and antibiotics in dental practice.  
  • How understanding alveolar bone composition and remodelling guides treatment planning in periodontics, extractions, implant placement, and orthodontics.
  • How the anatomy and function of key cranial nerves support local anaesthetic techniques, diagnosis of neuropathies, and management of sensory disturbances.
  • How vascular knowledge guides safe procedural planning, management of bleeding, and recognition of vascular complications.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description: The end-of-semester quiz consists of 40 questions in a range of formats, including multiple-choice questions (MCQs), drag-and-drop questions, and true/false questions, covering Week 1 to Week 4 content. The quiz will be delivered via Inspera and will run for 60 minutes, from 2:00 pm to 3:00 pm.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: Exams submitted after the end of the submission time will incur a late penalty.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.
